awd_titl_txt: Electronic Transport in Nanostructured and Amorphous Semiconductor Thin Films
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description: Composite materials consisting of nanocrystals within a thin-film amorphous matrix can exhibit novel properties not characteristic of either individual constituent. These composite structures, combining the advantages of amorphous semiconductors with the unique properties of nanocrystals may enable new electronic and photovoltaic applications. The goal of this project is to study the electronic properties of free-standing nanocrystalline films and amorphous/nanocrystalline composites as the nanocrystal properties are systematically varied. In order to elucidate the mechanism underlying the unusual conductivity in this type of material, recently discovered by the Principle Investigator, a variety of amorphous semiconductors and amorphous/nanocrystalline composites, synthesized under a broad range of conditions are investigated, testing various conduction models. A graduate student and undergraduate researchers work together on this project, learning a variety of materials synthesis and characterization techniques. The research is integrated with various outreach activities, promoting the importance of advanced materials research to a wide audience.

Technical Description: The goal of the research project is to elucidate the charge transport mechanisms in free-standing nanocrystalline films; composite materials of amorphous semiconductors containing nanocrystalline inclusions; and pure amorphous semiconductors. Samples are fabricated by employing an advanced dual-chamber co-deposition system, developed at the University of Minnesota, that enables growth of various composite materials of a nanocrystal Si or Ge embedded in a thin-film matrix of hydrogenated amorphous silicon or germanium, or an insulating silicon nitride. The material properties are evaluated by using structural (transmission electron microscopy, Fourier transform infra-red spectroscopy, and Raman spectroscopy), optical (transmission and constant photocurrent techniques) and electrical characterization techniques. The charge transport in nanostructured films is investigated by using 1/f noise spectroscopy that is highly sensitive to filamentary conduction processes, as well as thermopower and Hall-effect measurements, in order to explore the mechanisms underlying the recently reported anomalous hopping conductivity.

por.por_cntn:
Interest in nanostructured and amorphous semiconductors stems in part from their use in applications that do not require the high electronic mobility of single crystal materials, but rather call for semiconductors to cover large surface areas on a variety of substrate surfaces at low cost, including photovoltaics, thermoelectrics, plasmonics, medical x-ray imaging, thin film transistors and non-volatile memories. However, even though they are employed in several mature technologies, fundamental questions about the electronic properties of amorphous and nanostructured semiconductors remain.

Using the unique capabilities of a dual-chamber plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition system developed at the University of Minnesota, nanostructured thin films consisting of either free-standing nanocrystalline films, composite materials of amorphous semiconductors containing nanocrystalline inclusions, or pure amorphous semiconductors have been fabricated and their structural, optical and electronic properties have been characterized. The addition of nanocrystalline inclusions to an amorphous semiconductor matrix provides a new degree of freedom, in addition to impurity doping, chemical alloying and atomic bonding arrangements, with which the electronic properties of disordered semiconductors can be varied and controlled.

Composite nanostructured materials exhibit novel electronic properties not characteristic either system alone. With support by this grant, a novel persistent photoconductivity effect was observed in composite films of hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) containing nanocrystalline germanium inclusions (nc-Ge/a-Si:H), where the light-induced enhancement occurs even in films with a minimal photosensitivity and slowly decays away via a non-thermal process. We have also discovered a permanent enhancement of the conductivity of a/nc-Si:H when the films are irradiated with high-energy protons, suggesting that the composite nanocrystalline/amorphous semiconductors are promising candidate materials for high-energy particle detectors and satellite-based solar cells.

One of the most basic but also striking characteristics of charge transport in amorphous semiconductors is the observation that the temperature dependence of the dark conductivity is consistent with a simple, thermally activated expression, where the activation energy is approximately half of the optical gap. We have found that conductivity s in undoped a-Si:H, as well as composite films of a-Si:H containing nanocrystalline inclusions of either silicon or germanium (nc-Si or nc-Ge), and in hydrogenated amorphous silicon-germanium thin film alloys, is not in fact thermally activated, but rather is best described by an anomalous hopping expression where the tempertaure dependence of the conductivity ~ exp[-(To/T)3/4] where T is the temperature and To is a constant characteristic temperature. These results have been confirmed by another lab for n-type doped a-Si:H. Anomalous hopping conduction has also been reported for ultra-thin disordered films of Ag, Bi, Pb and Pd, two-dimensional electron systems in high parallel magnetic fields, ultra-thin quench condensed Bi films and carbon-black polymer composites. While there are models to account for a 1/T, 1/T1/2 or 1/T1/4 temperature dependences, there is no accepted theoretical model for a 1/T3/4 conductivity temperature dependence.

One common feature of many (though not all) of the materials systems that exhibit anomalous hopping is low-dimensionality combined with disorder, which can lead to conduction proceeding through filamentary structures. The spectral density of conductance fluctuations diverges as a function of the volume fraction of conducting material at a percolation threshold, making noise studies a powerful tool for investigating filamentary conduction. Conductance fluctuations were measured in hydrogenated amorphous germanium (a-Ge:H) which are consistent with previous studies of a-Si:H based films, indicating that charge transport is determined by inhomogeneous current filaments whose properties are time dependent. Random telegraph switching noise, and non-Gaussian correlations in the noise spectra are observed. This time dependence appears to be associated with the motion of bonded hydrogen in the thin film amorphous semiconductors, as similar noise behavior is not observed on polycrystalline germanium thin films. These data have been interpreted in terms of the Dynamical Current Redistribution model of Seidler, Solin and Marley, where if one segment of a resistor network transitions to a higher resistance state, the current it carries is reduced, leading to parallel current paths carrying a higher fraction of the current. Fluctuations in the connectivity and hence conductance of a given filament will then lead to correlations between fluctuations in other filaments in a natural manner, even if there are no direct interactions between filaments.

An improved understanding of charge transport in nanostructured materials benefits applications that require large-area, thin film devices and can inform other fields where charge or mass transport occurs via percolation structures. This project supported the training in all aspects of materials preparation, characterization and analysis of two Ph.D. students from under-represented groups and several undergraduate researchers.
